instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA: What is SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA? SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA is the data line of an I2C data line between the battery charging chip that creates PPBUS_G3H, the system management controller(SMC), the battery, and the battery indicator LED. If this line’s resistance to ground is too low because of a defective component, battery will not be recognized with an X on the icon and PPBUS_G3H voltage will be lower than it is on a good system..
definitions.SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL: What is SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL? SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL is the clock line of an I2C data line between the battery charging chip that creates PPBUS_G3H, the system management controller(SMC), the battery, and the battery indicator LED. If this line’s resistance to ground is too low because of a defective component, battery will not be recognized with an X on the icon and PPBUS_G3H voltage will be lower than it is on a good system..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Battery Issue
threads.message:
Hello,

Logic board had liquid damage, corrosion on <CHIP>U1930</CHIP>, and on the J6100 connector.
Replaced <CHIP>U1930</CHIP> and removed J1600.
LB appears to be functioning normally except it throws a PPT004 battery error when the internal diagnostics are run, even with a known good battery.
<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA</SIGNAL> appear to be working, at least <RESISTOR>R5380</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R5381</RESISTOR> are in good shape, and the voltage is close to 3.42 volts, and the SDA line is showing some fluctuations consistent with data. I don't have a scope though.
Battery detection is working.

Any ideas or places to start?

Thanks much,

Stefan

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Battery Issue
threads.message: If the machine works fine otherwise the PPT004 is probably an error for a non sealed battery. Chinese replacement batteries usually leave the controller in non-sealed state which will not affect anything. It does make it possible to simply reset cycle counter and full charge capacity etc. if you wish to do so. Sealed batteries require a password to access these values in the controller.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Battery Issue
threads.message:
Hmm, I will have to ask the supplier.
As far as I am aware these are OEM pulls that they rate by estimated capacity, but they could have ran out of stock and sold a replacement.

Thanks for your time.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Battery Issue
threads.message: Even the original ones can be "unsealed" and reset. This is what most Chinese do and then sell them as "new"
